abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Socio-Economic
            Development Support Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The
            project achieved most of its objectives, institutional
            development has been partially achieved, sustainability is
            uncertain, and the performance of the Bank was satisfactory
            while the Borrower's was deficient. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, adequate linkages,
            exchanges, and contacts are very important to ensure that
            studies and surveys lead to policy formulation. Second,
            simply subcontracting studies to foreign consultants,
            because of a lack of local capacity and in the interest of
            having the studies done within a reasonable time, does not
            build any capacity in government departments. Third, social
            funds are more likely to achieve their objectives when they
            have greater independence from the Government. Fourth,
            community involvement and support in the design,
            implementation, and management of sub-projects to be
            financed by social funds are very important to ensure the
            success of social funds. Fifth, in order for a social fund
            to start operations and finance sub-projects quickly, a
            number of conditions must be met, such as the various
            instruments needed for operations must be available.
            Finally, mixing credits and grants makes the management and
            operation of social funds particularly difficult and risky.
